questions.text: A female patient with a history of fever, photosensitivity, rash sparing nasolabial fold presents to OPD. Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by:

  • Multisystem involvement: Skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, and nervous system.
  • Classic symptoms: Fever, photosensitivity, and rash sparing the nasolabial fold (characteristic of the malar rash in SLE).
  • Demographics: More than 90% of cases occur in women, commonly of childbearing age.

The presence of fever, photosensitivity, and a malar rash sparing the nasolabial fold strongly suggests SLE.

Brief Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • (B) Dermatomyositis:
    • Features include a heliotrope rash (violaceous rash on the eyelids) and Gottron's papules (over knuckles), which are not seen in this case.
    • Photosensitivity can occur, but joint pain and fever are less prominent.
  • (C) Melasma:
    • A pigmentary disorder presenting with brownish hyperpigmentation over sun-exposed areas.
    • It lacks systemic features such as fever, joint pain, or photosensitivity-related inflammation.
  • (D) Rosacea:
    • Typically presents with erythema, papules, and pustules on the face, sparing the nasolabial fold.
    • Photosensitivity is not a hallmark, and systemic symptoms like fever and joint pain are absent.

Key Takeaway:

When a woman of childbearing age presents with fever, photosensitivity, joint pain, and a rash sparing the nasolabial fold, always consider SLE as the primary diagnosis.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• A sebaceous cyst (technically an epidermoid cyst) is a benign, encapsulated nodule filled with keratin material.
  • Common locations: Face, neck, trunk, genitalia, and fingers, though it can occur anywhere.
  • It presents as a slowly progressing, painless nodule that remains stable for years unless infected or inflamed.
  • It is unrelated to sebaceous glands and forms within the infundibulum.
  • These cysts may be associated with Gardner syndrome or Gorlin syndrome in rare cases.

Brief Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • (B) Alopecia areata:
    • A patchy, non-scarring hair loss condition caused by autoimmune destruction of hair follicles.
    • No cystic lesions are present.
  • (C) Trichotillomania:
    • Characterized by self-induced hair pulling, leading to irregular patches of hair loss.
    • No nodular lesions or cystic components are found.
  • (D) Tinea capitis:
    • A fungal infection of the scalp causing scaly patches of hair loss, sometimes with inflammation or pustules.
    • Does not present as a cyst.

Key Takeaway:

A sebaceous cyst is a benign, encapsulated subepidermal nodule filled with keratin. It is often misnamed but should be differentiated from inflammatory or infectious scalp conditions.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image.
questions.solution:
Contact leukoderma occurs due to the destruction of melanocytes following exposure to specific chemicals. Common culprits include:

  • Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH): Found in rubber gloves treated with this compound.
  • Para-tertiary butyl phenol (PTBP): Used in adhesives like bindi glue.
  • Para-phenylenediamine (PPD): Found in hair dyes and a leading cause of cosmetic-related leukoderma.

These chemicals trigger a toxic reaction, resulting in depigmentation of the skin.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

(A) Vitiligo:

An autoimmune condition causing melanocyte destruction but not due to chemical exposure. It has a progressive course and often symmetrical distribution.

(B) Piebaldism:

A rare genetic condition characterized by stable, congenital hypopigmented patches due to melanocyte migration defects. Typically present since birth.

(C) Albinism:

A genetic condition resulting in a lack of melanin production in the skin, hair, and eyes. Unlike contact leukoderma, it is systemic and not due to external exposure.

Key Takeaway: Contact leukoderma is an acquired depigmentation caused by chemical exposure, unlike autoimmune or genetic conditions like vitiligo, piebaldism, and albinism.

questions.text: Identify the arthropod shown in the image.
A patient presented with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base on the trunk as shown in the image. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia after primary infection (chickenpox).

  • Clinical Features:
    • Pain and burning sensation along the affected dermatome.
    • Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base distributed unilaterally along dermatomes.
  • Treatment:
    • Antiviral medications like acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir, administered within 72 hours of symptom onset to reduce complications and duration.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Herpes Simplex:
    • Usually presents as grouped vesicles on mucocutaneous junctions (e.g., lips or genital area). Does not follow a dermatome pattern and is recurrent in nature.
  • (C) Molluscum Contagiosum:
    • Caused by the poxvirus, presenting as multiple pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. It is painless and not vesicular.
  • (D) Chickenpox:
    • Caused by primary varicella-zoster virus infection, presenting as a polymorphic rash (vesicles, papules, and crusts) that is generalized and pruritic, often involving the trunk and extremities.

Key Takeaway: Herpes zoster presents as unilateral painful vesicles along a dermatome, distinguishing it from other conditions with vesicular or papular rashes.

questions.text: One year old child presents with eczematous dermatitis over face (Image shown). His mother has the history of bronchial asthma. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, non-contagious inflammatory skin condition commonly present in infants. It is strongly associated with a family or personal history of atopy (e.g., asthma, hay fever).

  • Clinical Features:
    • Eczematous dermatitis typically appears on the face in infants.
    • Severe itching, redness, oozing, and cracked skin are hallmark signs.
    • Symptoms are worsened by scratching, leading to an increased risk of secondary infections.
  • Cause:
    • Genetic factors (e.g., filaggrin deficiency).
    • Immune system dysfunction and skin barrier abnormalities.
    • Environmental triggers.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Infantile Eczematous Dermatitis:
    • A descriptive term, but it lacks specificity and does not encompass the atopic nature or association with family history of atopy.
  • (B) Seborrheic Dermatitis:
    • Presents with greasy scales on areas rich in sebaceous glands (e.g., scalp, face, neck). It is not related to atopy and does not typically cause severe itching or oozing lesions.
  • (C) Airborne Contact Dermatitis:
    • Caused by exposure to airborne allergens or irritants, affecting exposed areas like the face and neck in adults. It is uncommon in infants and does not have a strong association with atopy.

Key Takeaway:

Atopic dermatitis in infants commonly presents with eczematous lesions on the face and is associated with a personal or family history of atopy (e.g., asthma, hay fever). Recognizing the genetic and environmental triggers is crucial for management.

questions.text: Velvety hyperpigmentation on flexural area of individual suffering from diabetes. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
Acanthosis nigricans is a dermatological condition characterized by velvety hyperpigmentation of flexural areas (e.g., neck, axillae, groin). It is commonly associated with:

  • Diabetes: Insulin resistance leads to increased insulin levels, which stimulate keratinocyte proliferation and IGF-1 release.
  • Obesity and Metabolic Syndrome: Contribute to insulin resistance.
  • Drug-Induced: Triggered by medications such as nicotinic acid or oral contraceptives.
  • Malignancies: Particularly gastric adenocarcinoma in paraneoplastic forms.
  • Histopathology: Shows hyperkeratosis but no true acanthosis (thickening of the epidermis) or pigment accumulation in

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Becker's Nevus:
    • A benign pigmented lesion with hyperpigmentation and hair growth, typically seen on the shoulder or chest. It is not associated with diabetes or metabolic syndrome.
  • (C) Lichen Planus:
    • An inflammatory condition presenting as pruritic, purple, polygonal papules, often on the wrists, legs, or oral mucosa. It does not present as velvety hyperpigmentation.
  • (D) Erythrasma:
    • A superficial bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, presenting as reddish-brown patches in intertriginous areas. It fluoresces coral-red under Wood's lamp and is not associated with diabetes or insulin resistance.

Key Takeaway:

Acanthosis nigricans is a hallmark of insulin resistance and metabolic disorders, presenting as velvety hyperpigmentation in flexural areas.

Acanthosis nigricans

Erythema multiforme (EM) is a self-limiting hypersensitivity reaction of the skin and mucosa. It is characterized by the formation of target lesions and is triggered by several factors, including infections, medications, and autoimmune conditions.

  • Triggers:
    • Idiopathic: Most common cause.
    • Infections:
      • Herpes simplex virus (most common infectious trigger).
      • Mycoplasma pneumoniae (second most common).
    • Drugs:
      • Antimalarial drugs, NSAIDs, and antibiotics are common drug triggers.
    • Connective Tissue Disorders (CTD):g., systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
    • Malignancies: Leukemia and other cancers.
    • Food Additives: Rarely implicated.
  • Typical Lesion:
    • Target or Bulls-Eye Lesion:
      • Central dusky/purple zone.
      • Middle pale area.
      • Peripheral erythematous ring.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Celiac Disease:
    • More commonly associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, not erythema multiforme.
  • (B) ITP (Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura):
    • Presents with petechiae, purpura, and mucosal bleeding due to low platelet counts, not hypersensitivity reactions.
  • (D) Leukemia:
    • Although malignancies like leukemia can rarely trigger erythema multiforme, antimalarial drugs are a more common cause.

Key Takeaway:

Erythema multiforme is a hypersensitivity reaction most commonly triggered by infections and drugs, with characteristic target lesions as a diagnostic hallmark.

choices.text: Both dermis & ectoderm are derived from ectoderm
Skin accounts for total of 15% of body weight
Most of the cells in skin are keratinocytes derived from ectoderm
Dermis is made up pf type 1 and type 3 collagen in 8:1 ratio

questions.text: All are true about skin except:
questions.solution:
• The statement that "both dermis and ectoderm are derived from ectoderm" is incorrect.
    • Epidermis (including keratinocytes, melanocytes, and Merkel cells) is derived from the ectoderm.
    • Dermis and Langerhans cells originate from the mesoderm.
    • Hence, the dermis is not ectodermal in origin.

Explanation of the Incorrect Options:

  • (B) Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight:
    • True. Skin is the largest organ of the body, weighing approximately 4-5 kg, which accounts for about 15% of the body weight.
  • (C) Most of the cells in the skin are keratinocytes derived from ectoderm:
    • True. Keratinocytes are the predominant cell type in the epidermis, forming the outermost protective layer, and are derived from the ectoderm.
  • (D) Dermis is made up of type I and type III collagen in an 8:1 ratio:
    • True. The dermis is primarily composed of type I (80%) and type III collagen (10%), with a ratio of 8:1. This ratio increases with age due to decreased type III collagen.

Key Takeaway:

The epidermis originates from the ectoderm, whereas the dermis originates from the mesoderm. This distinction is fundamental to understanding the embryological development of the skin.
